review.title: A General Modifier-based Framework for Inconsistency-Tolerant Query Answering
review.abstract: We propose a general framework for inconsistency-tolerant query answering within existential rule setting. This framework unifies the main semantics proposed by the state of art and introduces new ones based on cardinality and majority principles. It relies on two key notions: modifiers and inference strategies. An inconsistency-tolerant semantics is seen as a composite modifier plus an inference strategy. We compare the obtained semantics from a productivity point of view.

sections.heading: Elementary and Composite Modifiers
sections.text: First of all, we present three classes of elementary modifiers, expansion, splitting and selection. For each class, we consider a "natural" instance, namely a positive closure that can be divided into repairs and the largest elements can be selected (i.e., maximum choices can be combined to define composite modifiers). Considering the three natural instances of these modifiers, we show that their combination produces exactly eight different composite modifiers. sections.heading: Inference Strategies for Querying an MBox
sections.text: The Universal Conclusion Strategy states that a conclusion is valid if it follows from T and each ABox in M. It is a standard method of deriving conclusions from conflicting sources, used, for example, in Standard Logic (Reiter 1980), where one accepts only conclusions derived from any extension of a Standard Theory. The Existential Conclusion Strategy (also called the Brave Conclusion Relationship) considers all conclusions drawn from T and the intersection of all ABoxes to be valid. < M The Existential Conclusion is a very reasonable and conservative conclusion relationship, since it only takes into account statements shared by different ABoxes.
